text:
RAKESH SURI: You know,
it's interesting.

In health care, we all thrive on
energy, happenings, challenges,
and crises, actually.
You're part of the solution.

And that's what makes
it so satisfying.

It's why many of us
went into medicine.

When something of the
magnitude of the COVID pandemic

becomes a reality,
just jumping to action

too quickly without
understanding
is a cardinal error.

And therefore, the
algorithm we put in place

is stopping the mind, slowing
things down for just a moment,
gathering your senses.

Take a deep breath, and
really assess the situation.
[MUSIC PLAYING]

You wake up one day, and
you had a business plan.
You had a scorecard.
You had a strategy.

And by the way, COVID
has made it irrelevant.
There's a fog.

You don't know what
tomorrow will look like.

Moreover, you cannot possibly
imagine what a month,

or ascertaining what a year,
will entail and the need,

as a leader, to be able to
put some structure around what

you're doing now, what
you're going to do tomorrow,

and what you're going to do for
the weeks and months to come.

If this wasn't as bad as
people said it would be,
what would that look like?

If this was worse
than anybody imagined,
what would that look like?

Then you almost set a
mental map for yourself.

And then you peg where you
are on that map virtually
every day.

And then you have to
start to align everybody

that you're interfacing
with-- your leadership

team, your organization--
around a common worldview.

It's very important
through a crisis like this

to be clear about leading with
vision, clarity, and purpose.
[MUSIC PLAYING]

The quickest way to
disempower your leadership

team and your executives
in an organization

during a crisis like
this is paradoxically
to be working, quote, "harder."

In this particular
COVID crisis, showing up

at work when you're worn
out, physically depleted,

your immune system is
down, you haven't slept,

you haven't eaten
nutritious foods,

is a surefire way to
get sick and become
an ineffective leader.

Being a pace-setting leader
and outpacing everyone

else as a badge of honor, we
know, is the wrong thing to do.

And by the way,
it's not effective.

Obviously, work
days can go long.

I also know,
paradoxically, the longer I

stay and don't rely on
one of my team members

to take over for me
when I'm exhausted,

the worse the
decisions that we make

and paradoxically the
less we're able to be
effective in our roles.

So by about 7:00 or 8:00, I need
to be eating dinner, calming

my mind, finishing up calls,
personally or professionally,

and then winding down by
about 10 o'clock to get in bed

and have a solid six to
seven hours of sleep.

So a combination
of sleep, exercise,

mindfulness, meditation,
a healthy diet,

leveraging colleagues, and
having a social interaction

with colleagues,
friends, and family,

that, in essence,
is a package that

is absolutely essential
for any human being

but particularly human
beings and leaders who

are particularly stressed
during any crisis.

A leader adhering
to those things

is going to be an
effective leader.
[MUSIC PLAYING]

We empowered those who were
willing to step up and take

on the leadership role
in the COVID task force.

And these were some
seasoned leaders,

some less-seasoned leaders,
and some nascent leaders--
people who had never led before.

But they were
passionate, and they
wanted to make a difference.

And indeed, that's
been the case.

They have stepped up and
really made an impact

in helping us tackle this
pandemic from our vantage
point.

Listen, we don't have the
answers at the boardroom table.

I mean, we're not
in these positions

because we have all the
answers to every situation.

But amongst 6,000
caregivers who are

some of the most brilliant,
empowered, ambitious,

thoughtful, and caring people
that I've ever met in my life,
we knew they had the answers.
[MUSIC PLAYING]
